facts.text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2631 of 1967 filed by appellant for abatement of Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Miscellaneous Petition,No. 2631 of J967  Application for abatement of Appeal . Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave challenging judgment and order dated April 20, 1965 of Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 1602 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 1602 of 1963. C. Agrawala and P. C. Agrawala, for the petitioners appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant on June 15, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, on June 15, 1965, granted special leave to the appellant, to appeal against the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant was defendant in suit instituted by respondents under section 209 of U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 for recovery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the defendant, in a suit instituted by the respondents, under s. 209, of the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U.P. Act 1 of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Abolition Act .

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed to be bhumidar of the land in question and sued for possession on ground that appellant was trespasser not entitled to possession.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, claiming to be a bhumindar of the land, in question, instituted the suit, out of Which the second appeal arose, against the appellant, for recovery of possession of the property, on the ground that the appellant was a trespasser and that he was number entitled to remain, in possession of the property.

facts.text: Trial Court and Appellate Court held plaintiff was bhumidhar and appellant failed to establish tenancy right, neither sirdar nor asami, but trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court, as well as the Appellate Court, have held that the plaintiff was the bhumidar, and the appellant has number established his tenancy right in the property, and, as such, he was neither a sardar number an asami. On the other hand, the findings are that the appellant is only a trespasser.

facts.text: Plaintiff's suit was decreed by trial court and appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings, the plaintiffs suit was decreed.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court agreed with lower courts and dismissed second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, thereupon, challenged the decision of the two subordinate companyrts In second appeal, before the High Court of Allahabad. The High Court has agreed with the companyclusions, arrived at by the Subordinate companyrts, and dismissed the second appeal.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh published notification dated October 22, 1965 under section 4 of U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1953 bringing plots in dispute under consolidation operations.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, after the grant of special leave, by this Court, the State of Uttar Pradesh has published in the State Gazette, a numberification, dated October 22, 1965, under s. 4, of the Act. The effect of that numberification is that the plots, in dispute between the parties in this litigation, and which are situated in the village of Pureon, Pargana Bayalsi, in the District of Jaunpur, have been brought under the companysolidation operation by virtue of the Act.

facts.text: Disputed plots situated in village of Pureon, Pargana Bayalsi, District of Jaunpur.

anchor.surface_text: the plots, in dispute between the parties in this litigation, and which are situated in the village of Pureon, Pargana Bayalsi, in the District of Jaunpur, have been brought under the companysolidation operation by virtue of the Act.

facts.text: Section 5 of U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1953 amended by Uttar Pradesh Act XXI of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that s. 5 has been amended, by Uttar Pradesh Act XXI of 1966.

facts.text: Appellant filed CMP No. 2631 of 1967 praying for order that Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 has abated under amended section 5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Based upon the amended provisions of s. 5 of the Act, the appellant has filed C.M P. 2631 of 1967, to pass an order that Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 stands abated, inasmuch as the rights of parties, with reference to their rights or interest in the property in dispute, will have to be agitated before the appropriate companysolidation authorities, in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent contended that suits for recovery of possession from trespassers do not come within purview of amended section 5.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. V. Gupte, learned companynsel, appearing for the respon- dent-plaintiff, has raised two companytentions  i  that suits, for recovery of possession of lands, from trespassers do number companye within the purview of s. 5, as it number stands, after the 1966 amendment, and hence numberquestion of abatement arises

facts.text: Respondent contended that amended section 5 is ultra vires as it takes away jurisdiction of Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: if the amended section applies to these proceedings, the legislation being one by the State Legislature, is ultra vires inasmuch as it takes away the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, to deal with the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that suit is covered by amended section 5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the suit, instituted by the respondent,. is companyered by the amended section 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that disputes between parties fall within exclusive jurisdiction of consolidation authorities under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The various provisions, companytained in the Act, also clearly indicate that disputes, of the nature which exists between the parties in the present litigation, are all number within the jurisdiction of the authorities, companystituted under the Act, to adjudicate upon.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected respondent's contentions.

anchor.surface_text: After a companysideration of the companytentions of both the learned companynsel, we ire satisfied that the stand taken, on behalf of the respondent, on both the points, cannot be accepted.

facts.text: Supreme Court declared Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 abated under amended section 5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that C.M.P. 2631 of 1967 is allowed and it is declared that Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 has abated, under the amended s. 5 of the Act. The civil appeal is also disposed of, as having abated, for the reasons given by us, when dealing with the civil miscellaneous petition.

facts.text: Notification under section 4 issued on October 22, 1965 takes in the area where disputed lands are situated.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy, that the numberification, issued by the State Government, under this section, on October 22, 1965, takes in the area where the disputed lands are situated.

facts.text: Appellant claims tenancy rights in the property.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant has number established his tenancy right in the property

Gupte, learned counsel, appearing for the respon- dent-plaintiff, has raised two contentions  i  that suits, for recovery of possession of lands, from trespassers do number come within the purview of s. 5, as it number stands, after the 1966 amendment, and hence numberquestion of abatement arises

Consolidation of Holdings Act because the rights of parties with reference to their rights or interest in the property in dispute will have to be agitated before the appropriate consolidation authorities

arguments.court_reasoning: Suit covered by amended s.5 and disputes fall within exclusive jurisdiction of consolidation authorities; appeal declared abated

arguments.claim: The scheme of the Act shows that questions whether respondent is bhumidhar and appellant has tenancy rights fall within exclusive jurisdiction of consolidation authorities

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant, Mr. Agrawala, has taken us through the various provisions of the Act and, according to him, the scheme of the Act clearly shows that the question, whether the respondent is a bhumidar and as to whether his client, the appellant, has got tenancy rights in the properties, are all matters now falling for adjudication, within the exclusive jurisdiction of the authorities constituted under the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: number companye within the purview of s. 5, as it number stands, after the 1966 amendment, and hence numberquestion of abatement arises if the amended

arguments.court_reasoning: Various provisions of the Act clearly indicate that disputes of this nature are within jurisdiction of authorities constituted under the Act

arguments.claim: Amendment by U.P. Act XXI of 1966 alters position from stay of proceedings to abatement of proceedings pending in courts

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also points out that while originally, under s. 5, as it stood before the amendment, the proceedings pending in Courts stood stayed, to await the adjudication by the authorities under the Act, the position has been now altered, by virtue of the amendment effected by the Amending Act XXI of 1966, the effect of which is to declare the proceedings pending before Courts, as abated.

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'every suit and proceeding in respect of declaration of rights or interest in any land' is comprehensive enough to take in suits for possession as court must adjudicate rights before granting possession

arguments.claim: Omission of specific reference to suits for possession in amended s.5 compared to original s.5 indicates conscious departure by legislature excluding such suits

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, in cl. b (i) of s. 5, as it originally stood, suits for possession of land were also expressly dealt with. But, under the amended s. 5, there is no direct reference to suits for possession of land. It is, on this difference in phraseology of the new section, that Mr. Gupte... has urged... conscious departure, by the Legislature, when S. 5 was amended, by omitting suits for possession of land.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: od stayed, to await the adjudication by the authorities under the Act, the position has been number altered, by virtue of the amendment effected by th

arguments.court_reasoning: Line of reasoning attractive on face but no merit; suits for possession covered as they require adjudication of rights or interest

arguments.claim: If amended s.5 applies to these proceedings, the legislation by State Legislature is ultra vires as it takes away jurisdiction of Supreme Court to deal with the appeal

anchor.surface_text: if the amended section applies to these proceedings, the legislation being one by the State Legislature, is ultra vires inasmuch as it takes away the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, to deal with the appeal.

arguments.court_reasoning: State Legislature has not passed legislation affecting jurisdiction of this Court; it declares suit abated, and Court takes note of subsequent event of abatement

arguments.claim: Suit instituted by respondent for possession is covered by amended s.5 as it involves declaration of rights or interest in land

anchor.surface_text: Suits for possession, as such, has not been expressly referred to, in the new section 5, but, in our opinion, the expression every suit and proceeding in respect of declaration of rights or interest in any land are comprehensive enough to take in suits for possession of land, because, before a claim for possession is accepted, the Court will have, necessarily, to adjudicate upon the right or interest of the plaintiff... Therefore, in our opinion, the suit, instituted by the respondent, is covered by the amended section 5 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Disputes of the nature between parties are within jurisdiction of authorities constituted under the Act to adjudicate upon

anchor.surface_text: The various provisions, contained in the Act, also clearly indicate that disputes, of the nature which exists between the parties in the present litigation, are all now within the jurisdiction of the authorities, constituted under the Act, to adjudicate upon.

arguments.claim: Salient provisions of the Act show subject matter of dispute falls for adjudication within purview of consolidation authorities

anchor.surface_text: The Act itself is one, to provide for the consolidation of agricultural holdings... Section 49 excludes the jurisdiction of civil courts... We have referred only to some of the salient provisions of the Act and they will clearly show that the subject matter of the dispute, between the parties in this litigation, are all matters falling for adjudication, within the purview of the authorities, constituted under the Act.

arguments.claim: Amended s.5 not ultra vires; State Legislature made provision within its jurisdiction declaring abatement without affecting Supreme Court jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The State Legislature has not passed any legislation affecting the jurisdiction of this Court. On the other hand, what the State Legislature has done is only to make provision in respect of matters, within its jurisdiction and to declare that a suit, instituted in a Court, within its area, has abated. The position, ultimately, is that this Court takes note of a subsequent event, viz., the passing of the Amending Act...

holdings.text: the suit, instituted by the respondent, is covered by the amended section 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the suit, instituted by the respondent,. is companyered by the amended section 5 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expression 'every suit and proceeding in respect of declaration of rights or interest in any land' is comprehensive to include suits for possession, as court must adjudicate rights or interest before decreeing possession

holdings.text: disputes, of the nature which exists between the parties in the present litigation, are all now within the jurisdiction of the authorities, constituted under the Act, to adjudicate upon

anchor.surface_text: The various provisions, companytained in the Act, also clearly indicate that disputes, of the nature which exists between the parties in the present litigation, are all number within the jurisdiction of the authorities, companystituted under the Act, to adjudicate upon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Salient provisions of the Act including definitions in s.3, notification under s.4, records and objections under ss.8-9, finality under s.11, possession under ss.24,28, judicial proceedings s.40, revision s.48, bar on civil courts s.49 establish exclusive jurisdiction over rights in land

holdings.text: the amended s. 5 of the Act applies to these proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Having due regard to the nature of this litigation, and the provisions of the Act, we are satisfied that the amended s. 5 of the Act applies to these proceedings. If that is so, an order has to be passed that the suit, out of which these proceedings arise, stands abated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit covered by amended s.5 and subject matter falls within purview of consolidation authorities under the Act

holdings.text: the provisions of the amended section 5 are not ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: The State Legislature has not passed any legislation affecting the jurisdiction of this Court. On the other hand, what the State Legislature has done is only to make provision in respect of matters, within its jurisdiction and to declare that a suit, instituted in a Court, within its area, has abated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Legislature acts within competence by declaring abatement of suits in its area; Supreme Court notes abatement as subsequent event without jurisdiction being affected

holdings.text: Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 has abated, under the amended s. 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The result is that C.M.P. 2631 of 1967 is allowed and it is declared that Civil Appeal No. 691 of 1966 has abated, under the amended s. 5 of the Act. The civil appeal is also disposed of, as having abated, for the reasons given by us, when dealing with the civil miscellaneous petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification under s.4 covers disputed area, suit covered by amended s.5 which applies to proceedings, leading to abatement without prejudice to rights before consolidation authorities
